issues.description: Constructor parameter mismatch for Animal: The UML in the problem statement specifies a constructor Animal(String, int) (name and age), but the template's example usage (Main.java) and the solution implementation use single-argument constructors (e.g., Seal("Clarabelle"), Pig("Doodle"), Goat("Buttinsky")) and Animal(String). This contradicts the UML and will confuse students about which constructor signature to implement.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the constructor signature consistent across artifacts. Either (A) update the UML and problem text to require a single-argument constructor Animal(String) (keeping only name), or (B) update the template Main and the solution to use the two-argument constructor Animal(String, int) and ensure concrete animals' constructors accept and pass both name and age. Choose the approach that matches the intended learning goals and apply it consistently in the UML, template examples, and solution.

issues.description: Attribute mismatch for Animal: The UML declares two attributes for Animal (name: String and age: int) but the solution's Animal implementation only contains a 'name' attribute and no 'age' attribute. The problem text and UML instruct students to initialize all class attributes via constructor. This inconsistency will confuse students about whether to include and initialize an 'age' field for Animal.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the attribute list with the chosen constructor design. If Animal should have an age field (per UML), add a private int age field to Animal, provide getter/setter, and change the constructor to Animal(String, int) so it initializes both fields — and update concrete animal constructors and all example usage (e.g., Main.java). Alternatively, remove 'age' from the UML and problem text if age is not intended, so all artifacts consistently use only the 'name' attribute.

issues.description: The UML in the problem statement declares Animal with two attributes (name: String and age: int) and a constructor Animal(String, int) (lines showing the Animal class and constructor). However, both the template/example Main and the provided solution use single-argument constructors (e.g., Seal("Clarabelle") in Main and Animal(String name) in the solution). The conceptual entity 'Animal constructor / Animal attributes' is represented inconsistently across artifacts: the diagram implies an (String,int) constructor and an `age` attribute, while the code uses only a single `name` parameter and no `age` field. This mismatch will confuse students about which constructor and attributes to implement and may lead to incorrect implementations or compilation/test failures.
issues.suggested_fix:
Make the representation of the Animal entity consistent across artifacts. Two options (pick one and apply everywhere):
1) Simplify the UML/problem statement to match the code: remove the `age` attribute and change the constructor in the UML from Animal(String, int) to Animal(String). Update the textual description to state that animals have a name and a single-argument constructor. This keeps the existing template and solution unchanged. 
2) Or, if age is intended, update the template Main and the solution to add an `age` attribute and change all constructors to accept (String name, int age) (adjust subclasses and usages accordingly). 
Prefer option 1 (update the UML/problem text) because the template examples and solution already use single-argument constructors; this minimizes student confusion and required code changes.
